reviewText:
A lot of people have the wrong idea about Trackmania Turbo. They are seeing it as a sequel to Trackmania 2 (also known as ManiaPlanet). The fact of the matter is that TMT is infact, NOT a sequel. It is merely a spin off for consoles, except that the developers brought it to PC so we wouldn't miss out too.

If you approach TMT as a side project, and not a sequel to TM2, then it is a very fun, enjoyable experience. It has all the stuff that is required for fun times with friends and other players online. Up to 4 player splitscreen, Double Driver mode (where two people control one car), and, of course a single player mode and track editor.

For those of you who are freaking out about the 'consolified' editor, calm down! The classic editor is still there, to access it, start making a new map, and then you just need to move your mouse up to the top of the screen (so the menu bar shows), and click on the cog/gear, and choose the classic editor :)

For video makers, the video editor is still there, too. It's accessed the same way (via the menu bar's cog/gear) on any of the main menus.

Physics-wise, Nadeo seem to have tweaked the handling of existing environments (Canyon, Stadium, and Valley). None of the tweaking has rendered the environments bad to play, and they still retain their exclusively different handling styles.

I can't give a complete coverage of optimization, as my system is fairly powerful. However, I have not had any performance issues at all, and no crashing either. However, it's running the exact same engine as Trackmania 2, so if you can run that, then you probably won't have any troubles running this!

Sadly, you cannot paint your car in a detailed way in this game (like in Trackmania 2). This, again, is because it is a spin off side game for consoles, that was also released on PC to keep us happy. I won't complain - they could have not released the game at all for PC.

All in all, this is a very solid fun game, and is worth picking up if you like fast-paced, skill based racing.



Final rating: 8/10 (two points lost for track complexity limit, this could have easily been disabled for PC!).

Trackmania Turbo was supposed to bring some fresh air into the series. The environments seem fun even though it's basically just the previous 3 environments plus a new one, but the COMPLETELY console focused gameplay ruins it, especially when playing the Rollercoaster Lagoon environment with keyboard instead of a controller. In addition to that the UPlay requirement completely disconnects TMT from the previous games, which means I can't really play with some of my old friends anymore.

Trackmania Turbo takes a good chunk of what was fun in the previous parts and turns them into something that is barely any good. Customization is now limited to paintjobs only, and not even different paintjobs per environment. Thanks to Uplay you can't change your nickname in ways you could do it before, and stuff like horns, avatars, custom car models/skins are all gone. Dedicated servers are also gone, which means that servers (or rather lobbies) can only be hosted on Nadeo's services, giving the host barely any control over how the server works and also eliminates things like Dedimania.

Overall Trackmania Turbo is really disappointing in a lot of aspects that made the Trackmania series so iconic and fun.

As a veteran, I am disappointed.

But since there is a demo out there, I'd recommend people to try it before making a choice on buying this game.

The main reason why I dislike Trackmania Turbo is because it leaves the existing Trackmania community behind, a lot of community driven features are not present in Turbo, the multiplayer doesn't allow for custom servers. The number one community feature just gets dropped for some lame-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• wannabe server system, allowing for no customization at all, no jukebox, no plugins, no dedimania to compare your times against the world and the server itself. What is Trackmania without record-hunting? Leaderboards exist, yes, but they're practically useless.

Turbo doesn't allow saving/editing replays for videos or exporting tracks to upload them on stuff like TMX, one of the community-heavy features that made Trackmania as big as it is today and effectively killing off those communities (for this game at least.)

The game itself is okay, but the fact that Nadeo disregards what made Trackmania such a success is simply outrageous.

reviewText:
I've been a longtime Trackmania fan, and this is the most fun I've had in a Trackmania game.
Trackmania Turbo is a skill-based hotlap racing game where you play in one of four unique environments on an infinite variety of player-made (or randomly generated) tracks. It's fast, it's difficult, it's technical, and it's crazy fun.

Pros:
-New environment (Lagoon Rollercoaster) feels like a remake of the Snow environment from TMUF, and it looks amazing
-Completely updated UI (It looks fantastic now. There are no 'janky' looking default font text labels popping up on the screen.
-Cool new art direction (All of the signage, scenery objects that are present in all environments)
-Unified gameplay experience (No need to close the game and open another just to play a different environment)
-Double Driver is a really fun new multiplayer mode
-New parts and smoother gameplay for existing environments
-Huge singleplayer campaign

Cons:
-From what I can tell, you can't save or edit your replays at this point. I hope this is either a planned or accidentally hidden feature.
-Less customization than previous Trackmania games (for example, no custom car models)*
*This might not really be a bad thing. I personally prefer the more coherent art style that this forces.
-You can't reassign controller inputs. The default layout is okay, but I'd prefer using the right analog stick for acceleration and brake (the default layout maps it to nothing at all).


Should you buy it?
-It's not an essential purchase if you are already invested in TM2, or if you prefer the deep customization of TM2.
If you're looking to get into Trackmania, or if you want a more unified experience, this game is worth getting. Despite the bad reviews, this game is highly appealing and very fun in my opinion, and I think you'll have fun with it too. Best 6 out of 10 -Steam" I've ever played."

There‚Äôs a terrible bias in many of the reviews posted so far. I felt inclined to post my own review to cater to people who may not have a problem with Uplay or Ubisoft. This is largely because real downsides in the game‚Äôs design are being completely ignored. Uplay has very rarely caused me problems. Some of the more recent updates to Uplay have made it less ‚Äúintrusive.‚Äù If you already have a Uplay account and other newer Ubisoft games, then there‚Äôs absolutely nothing to worry about when it comes to Uplay.

Should you buy this game if you are a long time player of Trackmania games? That‚Äôs exactly what I did. I‚Äôve been playing different versions of Trackmania for years. My experience with the game is probably different from many PC gamers. I played this game primarily in a couch co-op/party play type of setting with friends. Single player and internet play was something I barely touched during the years that I‚Äôve played previous Trackmania titles. Playing with friends in the same room meant playing hot seat. I‚Äôve played countless hours of incredibly entertaining Trackmania hot seat over the years. My Trackmania gaming experience was based on speed, precision (taking inches off corners) and friendly but aggressive competition. I‚Äôve never not had a version of this game installed somewhere. Does Trackmania Turbo deliver that same experience? Yes. Does it add to that experience? Yes.

We now have track and vehicle types that change the way you need to drive because of the handling and terrain combination. This is great because it adds a certain kind of ‚Äúvariety‚Äù to the racing. We also have split screen and different multiplayer modes. The new multiplayer modes are where I think the execution was faulty. Modes like ‚Äúmono screen‚Äù are hidden until you provide button codes to activate them. What you can immediately infer is that you‚Äôre left to understanding the modes yourself. How do I perform stunts or battle my friends? How do I mix modes up? None of this is immediately obvious. Getting the full hot seat playability out of the game is, unfortunately, a challenge. I fail to see why the game was designed this way. Wouldn't it have been wiser to fully open the local multiplayer modes of the game and provide enough information for us to immediately jump into playing?

I can't comment on the difference between the single player and online experience between this game and past games but I can say that the single player is fun and challenging; it is exactly what I expected from Trackmania and more.

Believe it or not, I'm not giving Turbo a negative review because HURR DURR MUH CUSTOM MODELS AND HORNS

It's nice to have a Trackmania game that has all of it's enviornments in one game, a Trackmania game that's not plagued with crap surrounding the screen in multiplayer...a Trackmania game that's purely about getting to the finish line in the fastest time. Turbo knows what it is, and it handles it's purpose as a time trial game exceedingly well. However, Trackmania Turbo DOES have enough flaws that makes it hard to recommend to veterans of the series.

The biggest thing is the way the cars handle. The enviornment that feels the best is probably Canyon; the cars in Canyon feel a bit heavier than in TM2 but they still retain their fun drift physics. That part of the game feels great. It's just a little less responsive, unfortunately. Likewise, the Stadium cars feel heavier and less responsive as well, and considering how popular Stadium is I think they should have left it alone. In stark contrast, the Lagoon cars are twitchy as all hell and you can complete all of the White tracks without even touching the brakes once. The twitchiness would be ok, but the controller deadzone is incredibly small and there's no obvious way to change it. If you're trying to play Lagoon on keyboard, God help you. The worst of the bunch is Valley. Valley was unpopular in TM2, and it's still just as bad. Those cars have a stupidly wide turning radius until you gently tap the brakes, and then they suddenly have incredibly massive oversteer. And that's just on pavement; Valley cars control like pure crap on dirt, and there's a lot of dirt in Valley.

This wouldn't be nearly as bad if you could tackle one enviornment at a time, but you cant. First you do the 10 White tracks in Canyon, which unlocks the first 10 White tracks in Valley, and so on. Doing tracks in one enviornment should unlock more tracks in the same enviornment; that way, the player has time to really hone their skills in one before moving on to another. In Turbo, as soon as you get used to one enviornment, you have to move to another. It's not done very well.

Furthermore, this is a REALLY lazy port. I know this is mainly a console game that's also seeing a PC release, but this is really sad coming from a developer that created originally Trackmania as a PC exclusive series. The options that you can change are almost as limited as Dark Souls. Visually, the game's pretty attractive, but I wish there was more that I could control.

Tl;dr, if you're a Trackmania veteran you're probably not going to like the changes that have been made to the existing enviornments. If you're a new player, you'll probably ge able to get used to it fairly quickly. Hopefully Nadeo turns their attention back to TM2 quickly, because I think I'm gonna pass on Turbo.

After some cooling down and thinking, I think I have figured out what it is about this game that irks me so much.

I initially thought that the Uplay implementation was my primary concern with this game. While Uplay implementation is still definitely reason enough in itself for me to give a game a bad rating, it isn't the final nail in the coffin in this case.

What irks me is the deceptive way it was marketed. Sure, one could definitely make the arguement that they didn't technically lie to consumers. But failing to address things or make things clear is equally bad. reviewText:
Trackmania has had a bit of a troubled past. Their first major hit 'Trackmania Nations' was free to play, and played by hundreds of thousands of people simultaneously worldwide. A combination of Trackmania 2 being divided by gameplay type (canyon, valley, stadium) and the games no longer being free to play started to harm the games reputation - the playerbase was dwindling, as fans were so divided amongst several versions of the game, they all appeared to be dead. Trackmania Turbo aims to fix that.

First and foremost, this game has uPlay and requires a separate account. You can't escape this, even the console version asks you to register and use an account separate from your PSN/XBL ID. It's not really worth complaining about in this context as equal effort is required no matter your platform of choice.

As far as PC options go, it's barebones and actually quite bad in a few instances. True fullscreen mode is hit or miss; enabling it on my PC shows the interface at the correct aspect ratio, but 3d elements of the game are rendered in 4:3 then stretched to 16:9, which looks awful, as are the the uplay and steam overlays. Getting a proper 16:9 ratio required that I played the game in borderless window mode. There are no options to change your controller bindings, and detection of xinput pads can be spotty, too - my Xbox 360 controller is detected by the game, but actually operates in Dinput mode, which means only the right or left trigger can be active at any given time. They are detected as the same axis. For drifting and braking, this requires me to rely on tapping 'A' to initiate a drift, and I must fully release the right trigger to brake at all. Graphics options are equally barebone, and setting the water to 'highest' actually causes graphical defects.

However, these are elements that can be worked around - using a different controller (such as a DS4 or Xbox One controller) properly detects and uses Xinput functionality, allowing you to hold the right trigger to accelerate and tap the left trigger to initiate a drift just like you can on the consoles. Once you're logged into uPlay, you can set it to remember your credentials and you'll never have to think about it again. Playing in borderless window mode is indistinguishable from fullscreen mode and as an added bonus, eliminates screen tearing without having to enable vsync, plus you can alt tab quickly from the game. Graphically speaking, the game is on par with the console versions even at the medium settings, and seems to be optimized well - my modest rig can easily run the game at 60+fps. Patches are reportedly on the way to fix issues with controllers.

I won't get too in-depth on how this game compares to previous titles, because frankly, as Nations went on, the dedicated servers and level of customization available to players converted the interface into a huge mess, and the maps you could race on became less fun to a casual player over time, as the diehard fans demanded more difficult, puzzle-like maps to play on.

What you get here is a 200 map-strong campaign, spread across 4 unique playstyles. Each car handles very differently, and for the first time in the series, each mode is truly united - the interface seamlessly transitions you from environment to environment, because they are all actually part of a single game, an improvement over previous entries in the series. You can join a server that runs maps from multiple environments, also a first for the series.

The game is very fast paced and has many arcade qualities to it. One perk of playing on PC is dramatically improved loading times - my time on the beta and later on, the demo for the PS4, had me waiting upwards of 25 seconds to load into a new map. Installing this game to an SSD on my PC has reduced that time to a mere 7 seconds, and i'm operating on a lower end SSD, too. The controls are responsive, and there's no stuttering or wait times to restart the entire map or from your previous checkpoint. There are per-map and overall rankings divided into multiple sections, allowing you to see how you measure up to the world, your country, and even down to the state level. Aiming for gold is just the beginning - the game makes it very clear to you how you measure up, and the small nature of each track encourages you to keep trying until you achieve trackmaster (a hidden ranking beyond gold) or become one of the best players in your region.

Taking the game online allows you to filter servers down to something you can enjoy, and you race against real-time ghosts of up to 99 others on the server. It feels good to know exactly how you stack up against others not only on a world/country/state level, but how you fare against others in a more intimate, competitive environment that demands consistently good performance out of you. It's nice to be able to witness how others take on the course, too. A current problem lies in how the servers are handled, though - since they're hosted by the developers, there's currently no easy way for you to make a track and share it with others. Reportedly, they're working on a fix for this, but in the mean time, you still have 200 official maps to occupy yourself with.

I personally believe the game is very fun, and lives up to the Trackmania name. This game represents the best opportunity for the entire community to come together and settle on a single game. Many of the complaints you'll see in the other reviews are valid, but overblown. The worst problems very quickly move out of your way and aren't really a issue anymore, beyond the games initial setup.

reviewText:
A good Trackmania experience for consoles, ported back to the PC
TL;DRI'd not be recommending this at full price. If you're a first timer who wants to try out TM, get the older freewares and try them out to see if TM is your thing. TM Turbo is more of a reboot of the series for the next-gen console age (& PC), and it's a fun and good reboot at that. If you liked the freewares and don't own TM2, this won't disappoint you much.

Full Review:A reasonably priced and equally good addition to the TM franchise. While it still plays like TM (acc,brake,left,right), the PC version isn't without it's issues. This game feels like it was made for consoles and to be fair, that's kind of true. It was a NinDS title years back and even the beta was only available for PS4/XBone. However, since the previous titles were exclusive to PCs, a full PC support is a given considering its history. If you're someone who's looking for that, this isn't that game.

Here are some things that I disliked about this PC version-
Settings (graphics,input) -> Move cursor up to the top of the screen and click the gear icon in the drop down bar. I'd have preferred them to be somewhere more visible, like in the settings menu.
Graphics Issues -> If you turn up all water reflection to max possible and look at the water, there's black dots everywhere. Solution? Turn down water reflection to medium.
(controller) ZeroVery little rumble on my F710 with XInput. Also, I coundn't find any controller layout screen.
(controller) An issue where if want to drift with LT(brake)+Stick, it won't register the LT as brake if RT(acc) is also pressed down.
Feature downgrade -> No private servers. All rooms hosted on dev servers.
Feature downgrade -> Servers have max 100 players, far fewer than it should've been.
Feature downgrade -> Customisation is restricted to paint jobs and decals. However, paintjobs/decals arent' car specific and are applied to every single car for all the environments.
The playlist is nice but there's only a couple in there and after the first few tracks, it's repetitive. More variety or an in-built custom playlist support would've been nice.
3 of 4 environments are from the previous game though it looks beautiful here. (Lagoon will be added to TM2 as DLC)
UPLAY BONUS -> If you're in a region, say, a country which you know is in the continent you've  been given the key for, you won't be able to activate it if Ubisoft thinks you aren't in the region. Tough luck; get a VPN and activate it anyway. I know it's UPlay but I didn't expect this.Nevertheless, the game is fun and a TM game at its core-
Race tracks are pretty varied, starting with simple turns that get more challenging as you progress. Feels more driftier but I could be wrong.
The environment is beautiful for a game where the sole focus is on cutting down every unnecessary millisecond off your lap time. And the map is open-world ish. If your eyes can see it, your drive can drive there.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=652090317
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=652090905
Carries over the track builder for countless hours of extra gameplay. Would've been nice if there was a Steam Workshop type feature for sharing user created tracks offline but I don't think that'll happen. Because you see, consoles don't do that, so PC can't.
Runs at a near constant 60fps at 1080p with every setting maxed out on i7-4710HQ + 860M.
No DLC or micro-transactions, at least none that I know of.Every positive point here isn't something new to TM and it isn't something that TM Turbo does better than it's predecessors. Yes it has got much better graphics and yes it now has a dynamic soundtrack. The game if anything, has been dumbed down. But I still like to play it and I have fun playing it. It's a good reboot, just not a good enough TM sequel.

TLDR: If Trackmania is not the most important game of your life, this game is perfectly fine for you. If you care about nothing as much as Trackmania, stick with Trackmania 2.

I'm gonna take a stand for Trackmania Turbo, Nadeo and Ubisoft, even if that's a very unpopular thing to do.
Trackmania Turbo is a beautiful, very polished game with 4 environments and a very capable multiplayer. It's a game that most certainly would not have been made - at least in this fidelity - if it wouldnt cater to a wider audience (I'm speaking of consoles). Previously, you paid 50‚Ç¨ for 3 environments, now you pay 40‚Ç¨ for 4. Good deal right there.
This issue many people seem to have is that you cant mod this game to your hearts content, whereas this was possible in all previous iterations. To want to mod all this stuff - cars, server, music etc - is of course a valid point. For some. Because i dont. I dont care about what my care looks like, they all drive the same anyway. I dont want my UI cluttered with some BS plugin someone thinks is funny or handy or whatever. The game's UI tells me everything I need to know. And for gods sake, I dont want some 14 year olds who spend their allowance on server hosting to dictate what music I listen to while playing. Because I've yet to listen to a decent song being played on any server in Trackmania 2.

So if you're not completely crazy about Trackmania, you just like playing it, this is the best Trackmania yet. If you are, you better stick to Trackmania 2.

This is a pretty good console rendition of Trackmania. It's all the environments in one package from TM2, plus lagoon. If you're a newer player interested in TM, this is probably a good buy. I don't have any gripes with the pure gameplay aspects.

There's some things missing that TM2 titles had, you can see lists in other reviews. So reluctance to switch over is pretty justified if you already own TM2 titles. And they did alter the handling of the cars a little, but as a canyon veteran, I can only really notice it there. And the lack of global track leaderboards (dedis, or even local server rankings) is a big thing too. I'm under the impression that TM2 Lagoon will still come out at some point in the future. And I hope Nadeo gives maniaplanet more love.

It's a fun game for what it is, a console trackmania game that was released on PC too. But it's not the sequel to TM2. So it's hard to recommend this game to a lot of the more hardcore fans of Trackmania 2, unless you want an early peek at Lagoon.

reviewText:
I have played every Trackmania game to date. This is primarily going to compare them, but also think of Turbo as a standalone game, over a series of topics;

1) Customization - Since the original Trackmania, players have always been able to customly paint cars without any set grids and whatnot. However, in Turbo, this isn't the case, as players customize their cars through set options that are gained by earning Gold Medals in the campaign. As much as this is a downgrade from previous installments, it finally gives a reason for those who just want to play the game to actually try the campaign. Would I call this a perk? That depends- for people such as myself, who have never been good at designing a car to begin with, yes. However, for those who can actually take the time to make a good-looking skin, no, this is a drastic loss.

2) Local Multiplayer - Hotseat has been around since the original trackmania, and split-screen since Trackmania 2. However, also in every previous installment was Profiles- a big loss specifically to me. Profiles used to be kept with the game and were for all those who played the game to enter their profile, change their car, make maps, and etc. However, Trackmania Turbo gets rid of Profiles, but still has Hotseat, in a more of an arcade fashion, where each player, when it is there turn, has the option to change their name using 4 letters. A massive loss, in my mind, however, the gameplay of the new hotseat is nice. Split Screen hasn't changed much, so not much to say on that.

3) Map Editor - A huge step up from the previous games. The Beginner mode, introduced in Nations & United Forever, helped people completely new to the game make maps with reasonably good detail in the background. Now, the difference between Normal mode and Advanced mode is one that I find perfectly fitting. For those who want to make perfect, amazing maps- Advanced mode is great, as it's completely barren from the start, and you can edit every little thing. For others who simply want a track to play on, Normal mode is very helpful, as you can build the map very quickly with various presets, and also have decoration filled in for you. Not to mention the landscapes are all as set templates. And the final amazing improvement to the Map Editor is the Random Track Generator- which I'm in love with. The Random Track Generator is literally an AI that pieces together the various presets from Normal Mode in a varying fashion each time. I'm still unsure as to what it prioritizes, but that makes the tracks even more fun.

4) Campaign & Singleplayer - Realistically, the only difference between this and the previous games is that the campaign actually has a reason to be played now- for unlockables. However, on the downside, it forces you to play all 10 tracks of the previous difficulty & environment before moving to the next, unlike previous Trackmania games. Not much else to say here.

5) Online Multiplayer - Being a part of the Nations/United Forever Dirty Deeds clan, I was playing multiplayer quite frequently on Forever. From what I can say, there's only a time attack mode for online so far, as compared to previous; Time Attack, Rounds, Team, Cup, etc. It's a bit of a let-down, but at the same time, most multiplayer servers from Forever were Time Attack anyways. Past this is also the stats for tracks, which people seemed to have valued. As much as I do miss seeing the world-wide fastest time on a track, it was a mod for Trackmania, never actually part of the game, so we can't really include it here. reviewText:
This game is getting way more hate than it deserves.  Just going to start by getting that out of the way.  I've been playing Trackmania for over a decade, and I feel like I'm the only diehard Trackmania fan that isn't being blinded by nostalgic fluff.

It's fast, it runs well, it looks nice, and the cars handle very well.  The physics for each pre-existing environment have been tweaked to varying degrees, most noticeable being Valley (I.E. Down and Dirty), where it doesn't feel practically impossible to turn on dirt without losing speed because you didn't have millimeter precision.  It feels much more fluid now than it did in TM2.

New blocks have been added for each environment, which helps keep it from feeling too samey to TM2, and adds some new surprises to each environment.

If there were one complaint I do overall agree with, it is the lack of leaderboards per track (I.E. Dedi's).  Although to a casual player, this would largely be a useless feature anyways, as Dedi boards only really tended to matter for high skill players, as they are the only ones that ever make it onto them.

That aside, the game plays great, and in the end, that is really what matters.  This is a time trials game with ridiculous over the top car physics, and it excels at being just that.  Although I haven't had the chance to try them, the new local multiplayer modes all look like they'd be a blast to play with friends, although it'd be nice if a few of them were available for online play (Though I understand why they aren't, as the majority of them would be complete garbage with latency between players).

Overall, this is a great spinoff of the Trackmania series (Yes, this is a spin off, targetted to console players, not a sequel for PC players, get over it).  It may be lacking some fluff that the PC crowd is used to, but that's all it's really lacking... fluff.  The game itself is fantastic and I'd recommend it to anyone who loves arcade racers.

reviewText:
My favorite arcade racing game in 18 years! Super recommended!

(Since F-Zero X and R4: Ridge Racer Type 4)

My initial review had ended there already, but since I'm a little shocked about all the negative reviews and comments about this game, I decided to write some more...

TMT is time trial based racing at its very best. The controls are responsive and nuanced, the track designs are outstanding, and there is a lot of content and variety, both online and offline. The fine developers at Nadeo have crafted a unique game with an abundance of imaginative features and ideas. It really succeeds to fill a void, that so many rather standardized modern racing games have left behind.

The game can be quite hard, especially the Rollercoatser Lagoon setting, and to feel some frustration is part of what Trackmania is about. Still, Nadeo has achieved a balanced progression in the campaign mode, which always gives you enough rewards and incentives to continue. I'm usually not too much into super challenging games, but TMT is absolutely addicting.

And the presentation of TMT is fantastic. A great color scheme evoking memories of 90's arcade racing, some of the coolest original cars and environments in a long time, and very nice signage and typography. While the later is not quite on the level of what Designers Republic did for the WipEout series, it does come pretty close sometimes. Many complaints here on Steam are targeted at the limited customization options compared to previous Trackmania games, but I find it hard to understand, why anyone would want to change any of those assets. The game achieves an amazing coherent art style, which is just a pure joy to experience.

TMT is more focused and polished than any Trackmania game before, making it my favorite Trackmania experience by far. I'm very inclined to say that this is one of the best arcade racers of all time!

reviewText:
If I was to rate this game for what Trackmania does well, which is a very fun game, and an excellent arcade driving experience, then as always it has to be 10/10........but

As others have said, if i was rating it with what we PC players have come to expect from the series, then 0/10.
This makes it hard to recommend, on the one hand, its Trackmania, and a lot of fun, and challenging in parts, and the new rollercoaster tracks you can create, are just a supurb addition.

But now with only rankings based on how long you play, the lack of world/local records, means those who don't play very often, but used to be able to get these records, will find little joy here now, as there is no emphasis to play, there is no community, just lots of people saying the same things over and over again with the press of a button.

I am not a console player, never have been, so don't know how this sits compared to other games, but this game as a PC game is severely lacking in what it should be offering, and it has only been out for one day, so this may change, but other key factors are missing, that we have come to expect from the series, including hide other cars, leaderboards, control customization, individuality and much more, and even though these don't take enough from the game to make it unplayable, it seems to take a lot from the game for those fans of the series, to make it not enjoyable enough to play.

Overall, its trackmania, you can still find enjoyment here even with the lack of features, just a slight dissapointed feeling of enjoyment.

reviewText:
EDIT:
Most of the problems mentioned in my original review still remain, but the more i played of Trackmania Turbo, the more i started to like it for what it is. It's a much different game than the old Trackmania games, but i realized that that was not what they intended. I can now reccomend this game, but i think i would still wait for a discount!

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
I've played countless hours of Trackmania United Forever, and was very excited for Trackmania Turbo to come out. I started the singleplayer campain and really enjoyed the 4 different environments and the basic racing. Just as i expected from a Trackmania. After around four hours i decided to try out all the other things a Trackmania has to offer, like the Trackbuilder, online multiplayer and the car customization. And i was so dissapointed.
This game is lacking so many multiplayer features compared to previous games, it's s quite shocking. There are no dedicated servers, no leaderboards, the UI is a big mess.. And then the Trackbuilder.. It becomes so obvious that this game is a console port. Everything is optimized for a controller, doing basic trackbuilding becomes a pain.
You want to name the track you just created? You're out of luck, it just gets a number as the name and you have no way of changing that. Want to share that track? That is also a big mess with some kind of confusing challenges and no way of just realeasing the track on its own.
You want to paint your car in some funny or creative way? Nah, they just deleted that feature, but you can now choose between some paintjobs that you can unlock by doing the campaign, yay.

The basic gameplay is fine, but with all the missing features and this game beeing an obvious console port, i just can't reccommend it in its current state. I regret playing more than 2 hours before realizing the mess that this game is, because i would love to refund it and wait with the purchase until they change the things i mentioned above. And i would advise you to do the same. If you have never played a Trackmania, buy ANY other but this one, they are all fantastic.

reviewText:
It's a fun game.  The controls are as tight as always, and the 80's arcade styling is a welcome overarching theme that ties the game together well.  The game is as fast-paced as always, and the integral trackbuilder is as good as ever.  Multiplayer has a nice variety of new and returning modes, and the single-player campaign is very nicely expanded.

On the flip side, the Trackbuilder STILL has parts only Nadeo can use, the Shaders and graphical quality are noticably worse than TrackMania 2 as a result of this being primarily a console game, and there still isn't a local splitscreen multiplayer where it's about getting the best time on a track, within a given time limit.  Seems that's still restricted to LAN party gaming.

The new Lagoon environment is awesome and the magnetic coaster is a great new element, but the Stadium environment could have used a little more love and the Rally/Desert environments are good but not overly noteworthy.

In short, if you have Trackmania 2 then only get Turbo if you want the coaster environment, otherwise just get the TM2 environments piecemeal.
